results.title: Film Australia: immigration
results.creator_credit: Penelope McDonald, Paul Byrnes, Oasis DVD and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The Australian Migration scheme and Film Australia were both set up just after World War II and were under the one minister. Hand in hand they set about promoting and encouraging migration through the film medium. Films where also made to encourage acceptance of migrants for Australians. To this day the Film Australia Collection holds over 100 immigration films. This interesting and informative DVD presents edited versions of eight of the collections most important films. The films cover a period of time from the forties to the nineties with a contemporary short documentary containing interviews with some of the participants and the film makers of each of the eight films. “Film Australia Immigration” also presents a series of clips arranged by subjects such as language, food, and identity. An extremely fascinating and authoritative exploration of immigration in Australia.

results.title: Film Australia's Australia
results.brief_description: The series deals with changes in the physical, social, cultural, political and economic spheres of Australian life. Utilises materials dating back from the beginnings of filmmaking in this country in the early 1900s.

results.title: Film and you
results.creator_credit: Donald Peters, Jean Palardy, Donald Fraser and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film describes how film councils are organised, and what they can do for the community. Different people like different things - for instance, Grandpa, who goes to sleep during a sequence on kitchen planning, wakes joyfully at the sound of a square dance. But all groups agree that they want films on their programs, if they can get them, and that is where the film council comes in. Animation shows how a council is set up, and how a number of organisations in an area can collaborate in buying a projector. We see projectionist training, and the public library becoming a distribution centre for films as well as books. Finally, we see film in action, as a variety of successful community projects are carried out, each directly the result of film showings.

results.title: Film and reality
results.creator_credit: Ernest Lindgren, Alberto Cavalcanti and BFI
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary which follows the history of Realist film from the earliest days until World War II. The film is presented in five sections - early Realist film and its divorce from film drama; foundations of the Realist film; romantic documentary on “Far-Off Lands”; the Realistic Documentary of “Life at home”; Realism and the Story Film - the Feature Film. Some of the films on display are: Nanook of the North, Rien que les heures, The General Line, Drifters etc.

results.title: Filling time
results.creator_credit: Andy Walker, Colin Thomas, BBC and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Conversations”.
Another in the series of films whose starting point is the sound track, made by pinning a radio microphone to the central character. The resulting ‘natural conversation’ was edited down to five minutes and the animator allowed free visual interpretation. This one is about a visit to the dentist.

results.title: Filing procedures in business
results.brief_description: Shows a large efficient central filing system functioning as an integral part of a well-run business organisation. The film is designed to teach students the correct procedures to be followed in operating such a filing system.

results.title: Filez, filez, o mon navire. J'ai tant danse.
results.creator_credit: Jim MacKay, George Dunning and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated interpretation of two French folk songs. Featuring the Quatuor Alouette and L’Assistance. ‘Filez, filez, o mon naivre’ 3.42 mins. ‘J’ai tant danse’ 2.20 mins.
